response.answer_text: I have a few scenarios I built in my head. I’ll start from the stupidest and go to what I think is the smartest. Or at least what I regard as the most respected way to get rich. Buy low, sell high.This is so simple that it pains me to put it on this list. However, we are going from the worst way to the smartest way, so this point has merit to that degree. This method never works. It’s not that it’s used incorrectly, it’s that it neglects key components of one part time and one part emulation.What do I mean?When it comes to buying low, you have to know what low is. Low might look like a 52-week low, but that’s only because you are looking at a company’s forecasts from the standpoint of 52 weeks. Many times, a company stands at a 52 week low, but they’re about to drop even harder because of setbacks that they haven’t recovered from or because competitors are about to eat the rest of their worth.For example, you could have looked at BlockBuster at 2005 trading at $10 a share. You would have seen that its 52-week high was around $30 a share, and thought it was a steal. They would have also recently declined to purchase a newer company called Netflix at the time—a company that was nearly worthless trading at only a few dollars a share.Except, BlockBuster today is completely worthless, and Netflix is trading at $400.In other words, looking at BlockBuster’s history gives you nothing valuable about where it’s headed in the future. The time aspect doesn’t tell you much. To that degree, you also can’t emulate a predictable future with the information, either.People have the element of luck on their side. Large trades can be made in the options world with relatively little capital. One trade can turn someone into a millionaire. You just need a little bit of dumb luck and a belief that your belief is different from everyone else’s.You can hit the lottery, too. It happens, after all.Dunning-kruger miracle.You buy some amount, say $50,000 of a particular stock you think will blow up for a reason you strongly believe. Your reasoning is wrong, because you know nothing about the industry and nothing about the thousand competitors. Your luck hits you something to the effect of a jackpot, and the company turns an incredible profit and miraculously gobbles up its competitors. The stock increases 100-fold, and your account now holds $5,000,000.Dunning-kruger hurts almost everyone. It is an incorrect assessment of your actual ability with your perceived ability. For a small amount of people, they end up with the correct result for the wrong reasons.This (almost) takes the cake for the dumbest way to get rich off of stocks.Your parents teach you about dividends—they’re also rich.Your parents teach you small things about how public companies operate. They teach you that you can earn a dividend if you hold stock in certain companies. You inherit $2,000,000 and it’s all invested in something like IEP—Carl Icahn’s fund.This fund yields a dividend of about 11%. You’ll make a nice $200,000 off the dividends, before tax, before you have to eat into the principal. If you are not a complete moron, you’ll have enough money for the rest of your life.It takes no genius to understand that capital begets capital. If you have a bunch of money, you can simply buy up things that other people can’t so you can reap the benefits of passive wealth from it.If you have that capital to begin with, you’re really going to have to put in a good effort in order to lose it.Incorrectly diversified portfolio.You’re thinking, “don’t you mean correctly diversified portfolio?” No, I don’t.I mean exactly the word incorrectly. People who actually make money on the stock market know that there is no money to be made by following indices. An index is not moved because the average of the stocks that make up the index go up. An index goes up because select companies in the index explode, causing those weights of the index to do most of the heavy lifting.We can statistically infer that if the index is moved by select companies, and there are weights associated with those companies, then the entire index lifts because of a 10 to 50-fold increase in the company.If your diversified portfolio captures said company, you enjoy the benefits of that uptick, too.That being said, if you have a portfolio that is accidentally diversified with the right companies, it will naturally make you a lot of money over time. People often end up with money this way if they’ve been regularly adding money to their portfolio after 20 years.These are not people making the infamous “10% per year on the stock market.” These are just people who hit the right companies in the right industries.A portfolio correctly diversified does get you something below average, usually 0–3% per year or so. But, you never know, out of thousands of diversified portfolios out there, some have to have really great companies in the mix that beat the odds by massive margins.Invest in brands you love and keep adding.This is where I start to enjoy people getting rich. You, me, and everybody else already use products we love.Whether that is Apple, or some semi-conductor company like AMD or Nvidia, or McDonald’s, or Google.We use these companies everyday. We use the products they make everyday.But instead of putting money into the companies, we just end up buying their products instead.There are a small select group of people who slowly contribute portions of their earnings into the companies, instead. These people have turned the system into a simple one.Often times, the system is quite simple. What makes money today is a good indicator of what will make money tomorrow and the next month and the next year and ten years from now.IBM made money back in the day and makes money now.Google made money then and makes money now.Amazon made money then and makes money now.Apple, AMD, Domino’s, ULTA, Toyota, Microsoft, Facebook, Starbuck’s Micron, Intel.The list goes on.People have gotten rich by sticking to companies they know make good products, and then adding to their equity stake in that company over time.If the company begins to drop? Double down and buy more.If the company starts to go up? Double up and buy more.You’re investing in the idea—wealth is what comes as an earning on that investment.The key here is that persistence and good values trump every other analytical metric.Concentration.Don’t put all your eggs in one basket.This is a stupid phrase.If the point of your endeavor on the market is not for retirement but rather to get rich, then your idea should revolve around putting all your eggs in one basket.In fact, most people get rich on the market precisely because they do put all their eggs in one basket. If you are putting them in multiple baskets, you might not know anything about the other baskets you’re placing eggs in.It’s important to really know a product. To that extent, sticking to your basket is the key to getting rich. I mostly deal with semi-conductors, and I hardly branch out to other industries unless I’m completely confident that my reasoning isn’t conflated with my ego’s ability to cloud my judgement.Here is a good example. When I was in college, I wanted to make money on the side. I knew a good deal about hardware, so I would purchase computer parts and fit them into rigs and then sell them on eBay for about 10–15% profit.Somewhere along the way I realized that AMD created products that rivaled Nvidia in the department of graphics processing units. They didn’t beat them, but they were either really competitive with their products or they were way too good of a value proposition for me to pass up. I would be able to make a bit more in my margin by using AMD chips instead of Nvidia and my customers didn’t notice a difference in their performance.In fact, when I was doing this, AMD was trading at about $2–3 a share. Today, it is above $35. It’s not a shock to me. It wasn’t then, and it isn’t now. They’ve always made great products. Concentration doesn’t strictly have to deal with industries, either. As I’ll show in the next, and most important point, there is concentration through the measure of data that transcends industry knowledge.You’re not looking for alpha, you’re looking for homoskedasticity.Someone will be looking at data, run some analysis they think is important on data, and then run a simulation based on that analysis that then fails to successfully predict realizable gains on the market.So then, the natural question—why?When most of us look at data, we need to understand all of the information that is given and then all of the meaning associated with that information.However, this is really not possible. What ends up happening is that we perceive to understand far more than we actually do.Which brings me to heteroskedasticity—we don’t want this.Heterskedasticity is defined as the circumstance in which the variability of a variable is unequal across the range of values of a second variable that predicts it.In other words, we have some data, and we are trying to make sense of that data. However, there is some unknown variable(s) causing the variability in our original model, making that model imprecise or leading us to believe something we shouldn’t.Simpler, we are trying to explain something we don’t know how to explain. Or, we are explaining something in the wrong way because we are missing something.What we want is homoskedasticity.Homoskedasticity is a condition in which the variance of the residual, or error term, in a regression model is constant.This means that the “variable” or “variables” that we have determined to be causing the changing in the price of a company are consistently influencing that change in a constant or near-constant degree.These are sometimes, technically, the unknown-variables we can’t or don’t know how to account for in our models that illustrate heteroskedasticity.The people who know how to do things to this precise of a degree are not financiers. A good example is James Simons, who runs Renaissance Technologies, a hedge fund that employees only mathematicians, signal processing experts, physicists, and statisticians.James Simons himself has a mathematics ph.d.Their fund has successfully annualized 70% returns for the last twenty years.They know something beyond the knowledge of industry.They’ve found the tools that work.They’ve found homoskedasticity.They’re probably the richest because of it.James Simons is probably the richest man you’ve never heard of.As of September 2019, his worth is approximately $21.6 billion. Every year, it goes up approximately a billion dollars.

Investing in companies through the stock market is often touted as a way to make real wealth for yourself, and even wealth for your family through generations. But how do people get rich from stocks, especially when the stock market is so volatile? When Apple went public in 1980, the price per share was $22. If you had invested $5,000 and held on to it until August 2018, you would have watched the share price grow to more than 10 times its starting price, to $227.63 per share. But even more important, the stock split 56 times during that time. With $5,000 to invest, you could have bought 227 shares in 1980. By 2018, after Apple had split its stock and changed its business model a few times, you would have 12,712 shares in the company. At $227.63 per share, your initial $5,000 investment would have grown to $2,893,632.56. When it comes to growing your wealth in the stock market, you need to have a working understanding of the stock market itself and be comfortable with long-term investing. Very few people become overnight millionaires off of a lucky stock pick, so don’t count on that happening to you. You can use financial advisor if you need help getting started. Budgeting your income is a powerful tool for your investments. Include your investment contributions in your monthly budget so you can track your investments over time. Look for areas that you can cut back in your spending so you can increase your investment amount. Whatever amount you already contribute to your investments, cutting back on another spending could mean investing even more. There's no shame getting help in organizing your finance. Facet wealth is a financial planning firm that pairs you with a dedicated Certified Financial Planne to manage your investments and savings, among other things. Picking one stock that is going to make you rich is a bit unrealistic. That’s why index fund investing is so popular. When you invest in an index fund you are broadly diversify By investing in many different companies in one fund, your investment in each fund is automatically smaller. This means you earn less from each company. But that way also, should some of the companies turn out to be lemons, you don’t lose as much money. What the Apple example clearly shows is that buying and holding a stock can be enormously beneficial for your finances. “Buy and hold” refers to buying stock shares and holding on to them for the long term, even when the stock market is down. short selling te strategy of buy and hold. People are looking to make money in the market in a shorter time frame, and they do that by “shorting” stocks Here’s the gist: You borrow stocks and sell them at current market prices and receive a cash payment. But since you’ve only borrowed the stocks, you need to replace the stock that you sold. And you are responsible for paying dividends for the length of time that you borrow the stock. When people short sell, they want the stock to drop sharply so they can buy it back at a much cheaper price. This means they can take home the difference. And sometimes the difference is a lot of money, which makes short selling a way you could get rich in the stock market. Contributing to your investments consistently over the years is a great strategy to grow wealth in the stock market. It's one strategy that works for the average American paycheck. Yes, many people do become rich from investing in stocks. But it’s important to understand what we mean by “many.” In absolute terms, which is to say the in terms of the value of the stock market if measured over an extended period time, investing in stocks does make people “richer.” But in relative terms, which is to say how individual players rank relative to each other in terms of their comparative returns, then people tend to underperform the market benchmark in the longer run. This is known as the random walk, whereby it is very difficult for any individual to outperform the market over an extended period of time, due to the complex randomness of stock behaviors. One way to deal with the randomness of stock markets is to simply purchase an Exchange-Traded Fund (ETF) that basically replicates the market return. In doing so, an individual’s return will always be the same (or very nearly the same) in any condition. This means, however, that in a downturn, the ETF will also fall by just as much as the overall market, which may not make an investor “richer” in any sense. Another way is to continually pick winners. There are a few companies that have built a reputation such as Blackrock, for consistent outperformance. Berkshire Hathaway is another one which uses Warren Buffet and his mentees’ acumen to continually invest in promising companies. Then firms such as 990 capital pool the money of high net worth (HNW) individuals to invest in specific mandates with the aim of outperforming through deep analysis. Many other names have become legendary, but as a whole, stock market investors do underperform the market due to its random walk nature. So people do become richer on an absolute basis, but consistently superior relative performance, the true acumen of a good investor, is a very rare commodity.

When it comes to investing in the stock market, it’s not so much about how much money you make, but rather how much risk you took to make the money you made. That being said, there’s a common misconception that you have to take huge risks in order to make a lot of money in the stock market. But truth is, great investors always take the least amount of risk for the biggest potential upside possible. This is called asymmetry.  Take deep value hedge fund manager Chris MacIntosh for example… He was able to 10x his capital during the last uranium bull market. He did this by never risking more than $0.10 to make a dollar, meaning he can be wrong 90% of the time and still make money. Reality is, great investors know they will be wrong on a lot of their investments, so they always position themselves so they can be wrong the majority of the time and still make money. Now, what do great investors like Chris actually invest in to get rich? They make asymmetric bets while taking advantage of the market cycle…  As you can see above, anyone can get rich from the stock market simply by front-running institutional capital. When a big fund like Fidelity or Goldman decides to invest in a sector, they are usually 10% of the buy volume every day for 6 months on the way up. And as a few large funds get positioned, herd mentality will take place and more funds will pile in, pushing the price higher and higher. So if you can invest in one of these sectors in the “Smart Money Phase,” your chances of making generational wealth is very high. Now, as funds pile in and everyone starts talking about it, this is when herd behavior takes place for retail investors. Because of this, investment bankers try to make money not by investing their own capital, but by packaging ETFs for retail investors who have FOMO (fear of missing out). This is typically the last capital that enters during a bull market, as well as when the assets are most overpriced/riskiest and upside most limited. This is why retail investors often don’t make life-changing returns. Because they always get involved too late during the cycle. However, front-running institutional capital is really easier said than done because when you invest in these kinds of sectors so early, you will naturally be betting against the consensus, meaning you will feel very uncomfortable/lonely, and often doubt your decision to get involved. This is THE trade-off for making life-changing returns. I mean, if it were easy, then everyone would be rich from the stock market. And to complicate the matter, there will always be sectors that will never get attention from big funds, so it helps to invest alongside someone who’s had years of experience in front-running institutional capital. If you’re interested in learning more about how you can front-run institutional capital with asymmetric investment ideas targeting 5–10x+ returns, I highly recommend Chris MacIntosh’s weekly newsletter. Chris retired in his late-20s, having made his fortune in asymmetric bets like… The New Zealand real estate (64x return)The last commodities bull market (10x)Bitcoin (20x)Shipping (27x)Capturing one bull market cycle and riding it for all its worth can be the difference between life in a cubicle and achieving financial freedom! Almost everybody wants to get rich, and the stock market has been shown to be a great way for people to do it, with annual returns -- on average -- that would double your money about every nine years. However, there's also a lot of evidence that plenty of investors underperform the market, and more than a few lose money. With that in mind, we asked three of our investing experts to tell us: What's the easiest way to get rich buying stocks? Here's what they had to say. Dan Caplinger: It's not sexy, it's not fast, and it's not the answer most people seem to want, but the secret to getting rich in the stock market is no secret at all. By focusing on the stocks of companies that have solid future prospects for long-term growth, you can set yourself up for monumental gains as years and decades pass. And by adding to positions in your favorite stocks month in and month out through automatic investing programs, you can give the power of compounding a boost and take advantage of favorable market conditions to add even more to your portfolio. That simple strategy has a number of advantages. First, if you have a set amount to invest every month, being diligent in making new investments every month will actually buy you more shares when your stock's price is down, helping you take maximum advantage of price declines to build up your overall position and adding to profits when the stock price turns back upward. Also, as long as you're mindful of fundamental changes that would justify selling your position in a given stock, having long-term confidence in proven businesses prevents you from falling prey to guesswork and emotional decisions that can turn out badly. Maintaining discipline can be hard, but the long-term rewards of smart investing are worth the effort. Jason Hall: There's a lot of evidence that investing in stocks is the best way for most people to get rich. It doesn't happen overnight, and it takes a lot of work to do well. However, low-cost index funds have made it much easier for people who aren't able or willing to dedicate the time to pick individual companies. Vanguard has really led the charge, with a number of funds with extremely low expense ratios -- the money the fund takes out each year to cover costs -- that track popular indices, like the S&P 500. By investing in these low-cost index funds, using the method that Dan describes, you can get close to the same long-term returns of that index. What's that worth over time? It can be an awful lot: BASED ON $10,000 INVESTED YEARLY, WITH ACTUAL S&P 500 RETURN EACH YEAR, MINUS 0.5% EXPENSE RATIO. If you'd been able to invest $10,000 yearly in the Vanguard 500 Index Fund (NYSEMKT:VOO) -- which tracks the S&P 500 -- starting in 1980, this chart shows your likely returns after the low 0.5% expense ratio was paid. This fund wasn't available back then, and there's no guarantee that you'll get the same kinds of returns going forward, but long-term buy-and-hold investors in index funds are far more likely to get rich than short-term traders, and with a lot less effort. Selena Maranjian: As Dan pointed out, patience and diligence are key contributors to getting rich through investing in stocks. But what you invest in matters a lot, too, and a powerful set of stocks worth considering is that of dividend payers. You don't give up stock-price appreciation when you invest in dividend payers. Shareholders of healthy, growing companies that pay dividends will see their stocks' values rise over time. But those companies that pay out dividends will be generating an additional return for their shareholders, and one that can be counted on more than stock-price appreciation, which is generally lumpy over time. If a company pays $0.25 per quarter, as long as it remains healthy, it will keep doing so, as cutting back on a dividend is a big red flag and a turnoff for investors. Better still, if the company is growing, it will likely increase its payout over time. Imagine this, as an example: You bought into a company when it was trading for $100 per share and it paid out $2.00 per year in dividends, for a 2% dividend yield. But if it hiked that payout over the next 25 years by an annual average of 8%, then it would end up paying out $13.70 per year 25 years later. Compare that to your $100 purchase price per share, and you'd be collecting $13.70 at that point from a $100 investment, for an effective yield of 13.7%! The stock would most likely be worth considerably more than $100 per share, too. Investing in strong dividend payers is a great way to get rich over time. Finally These three methods are slightly different, but share a few common elements like long-term focus and continual investing.

The Math Behind Getting Rich in the Stock Market  When Apple went public in 1980, the price per share was $22. If you had invested $5,000 and held on to it until August 2018, you would have watched the share price grow to more than 10 times its starting price, to $227.63 per share. But even more important, the stock split 56 times during that time. With $5,000 to invest, you could have bought 227 shares in 1980. By 2018, after Apple had split its stock and changed its business model a few times, you would have 12,712 shares in the company. At $227.63 per share, your initial $5,000 investment would have grown to $2,893,632.56. That’s using the stock market to get rich. Really rich. Long-term investing like that, over the course of 38 years, would have made you a multi-millionaire from just one company. So how do you make that much money from the stock market? While there is no one right answer, there are a few things you can keep in mind. 1. Buy and Hold What the Apple example clearly shows is that buying and holding a stock can be enormously beneficial for your finances. “Buy and hold” refers to buying stock shares and holding on to them for the long term, even when the stock market is down. Most legendary investors preach the glory of the buy-and-hold method. In 2016, Warren Buffet said, “The money is made in investments by investing and by owning good companies for long periods of time.” 2. Use Index Funds Picking one stock that is going to make you rich is a bit unrealistic. That’s why index fund investing is so popular. When you invest in an index fund you are broadly diversified. By investing in many different companies in one fund, your investment in each fund is automatically smaller. This means you earn less from each company. But that way also, should some of the companies turn out to be lemons, you don’t lose as much money. Rather than seeking the one stock that will change your life forever, index fund investing is good for the buy-and-hold strategy and getting rich in the stock market over time. 3. Budget for Investing Budgeting your income is a powerful tool for your investments. Include your investment contributions in your monthly budget so you can track your investments over time. Look for areas that you can cut back in your spending so you can increase your investment amount. Whatever amount you already contribute to your investments, cutting back on other spending could mean investing even more. 4. Short Selling Short selling is the opposite strategy of buy and hold. People are looking to make money in the market in a shorter time frame, and they do that by “shorting” stocks. Here’s the gist: You borrow stocks and sell them at current market prices and receive a cash payment. But since you’ve only borrowed the stocks, you need to replace the stock that you sold. And you are responsible for paying dividends for the length of time that you borrow the stock. When people short sell, they want the stock to drop sharply so they can buy it back at a much cheaper price. This means they can take home the difference. And sometimes the difference is a lot of money, which makes short selling a way you could get rich in the stock market. Shorting the market requires a knowledge of the market and an educated guess on when the stocks will go down. You don’t want to borrow them for too long, because you’ll end up owing a lot in dividends. If you're interested in short selling you can buy and sell stocks through a brokerage firm like TD Ameritrade. 5. Contribute to Your Portfolio Consistently Contributing to your investments consistently over the years is a great strategy to grow wealth in the stock market. It's one strategy that works for the average American paycheck. Many people don’t have huge amounts of money at any one moment to invest but do have smaller amounts that they can consistently contribute over the years. Consistency is a strong investing move. Say you start with an initial investment of $3,000. Invest $500 a month over 30 years at 6% interest, and you’ll have $523,022 in your accounts. At $1,000 a month, you’d have $1,027,897 at the end of 30 years. You can use a calculator like this one to see how different levels of monthly contributions can make a difference in your investment results. And if you’re just getting started, you can use an automated investing service like Betterment. For those with a bit more experience, try Personal Capital. It not only lets you keep track of all of your finances in one place, but also has a stellar wealth management service. 6. Understand the Stock Market and Stay Focused When it comes to growing your wealth in the stock market, you need to have a working understanding of the stock market itself and be comfortable with long-term investing. Very few people become overnight millionaires off of a lucky stock pick, so don’t count on that happening to you. Stay focused on your investment goals and stay calm in down periods. Let the market work for you.

Stocks Are Liquid When investing in stocks, you can choose how you want to get profits. The two primary approaches are to seek capital gains (selling our stocks at a higher price than we paid for them) and to generate cash flow (creating new money). Seeking cash flow is the Rich Dad way because it allows you to control the situation better than just buying stocks. Either way, the stock market offers us the ability to easily buy and sell your paper assets. This is liquidity. Liquidity is the ease with which an asset can be converted to cash. Stocks Are Agile When most people think about profiting from movement in the stock market, they think of one direction of movement: up. They don’t understand the concept that stocks are agile. You can learn to profit from a stock no matter if it goes up, down, or sideways. That’s very tough to do in business, but in the stock market, it doesn’t matter—because there are profit strategies for movement in any direction. Stocks Give Us the Ability to Scale There is a common misconception that you need a lot of money before you can begin to invest. Fortunately, investing in stocks allows almost anyone to begin their investing sooner rather than later. Because buying stock is buying only a share of a company, buying stock is more affordable for the average person than buying an entire company or starting a business. But the beauty of this is that you can own exactly the same stocks as a famous investor like Warren Buffett. The difference is that, as a new investor, you’ll probably buy a smaller number of shares than Buffett. A company you want to invest in may be a multi-billion dollar enterprise, but you may be able to get a single share of its stock for just $25. The cost effectiveness of stock allows you to scale up into your investing as you gain the means to go bigger. For the average person, this is a faster way to invest than saving up for decades to purchase a franchise or some other business.

Having a long-term time horizon can help you avoid making poor short-term investment decisions. A multi-year time horizon can also give you an advantage toward achieving superior returns by allowing you to make high-potential investments that others with a shorter time-frame would avoid. This article will elaborate on why being a long-term investor can help you achieve better returns, and illustrate how you can go about doing so. Long-term investors are less common than you might think I was a young associate at one of the biggest investment firms in the world. It was a typical evening in the middle of December, when many of us were working late. Another associate and I were discussing how he liked the prospects of a certain industry based on his long-term outlook when a recently-promoted portfolio manager walked in. He asked my colleague if he had any stocks that he could recommend. The other associate began to tell him about the group of companies whose long-term prospects he was just telling me about, but the portfolio manager cut him off, “I am so close to beating my benchmark this year. So close. I need something that will work by year-end.” There was a silence during which I looked at the portfolio manager and waited for an indication that this was his attempt at late-evening humor. There wasn’t any. Why to be a long-term investor Investing for the long-term allows you to take advantage of high return opportunities that others might shun.Consider an investment that is expected to result in a 15% annualized rate of return over 5 years, but for which the first 4 years are expected to be negative, with all of the returns coming in year 5. Quite a few investors, including many professionals, would pass on that investment. For professionals, this could be due to a misalignment of incentives, which may push them towards a shorter-term time horizon lest they lose their jobs or their clients while they wait for returns. For individuals, it could be due to the desire for instant gratification. Remember the marshmallow test that young children were subjected to in order to see how long they would forego eating one marshmallow in order to get two later? The behavior observed in those children opting for instant gratification is unfortunately frequently still present in adults making financial decisions.Being a long-term investor helps guard against behavioral biases. In Behavioral Defense in Decision Making, I wrote about the recency bias which causes people to over-extrapolate the near-past further into the future more than the facts merit. Taking the long-term view on an investment should cause you to think about more than just what has been happening recently in order to arrive at a reasonable conclusion, potentially lessening the impact of this bias.Long-term investing reduces frictional costs, such as trading expenses and tax impact. There is a dramatic difference in after-tax returns for a taxable investor with a holding period of many years compared to one whose gross returns are due to short-term gains. Over a 20 or 30 year period, that difference could translate into several percent of after-tax return per year. This difference is enough to cause someone who follows a long-term investing approach to retire years earlier than a person who is saving the same amount and achieving the same pre-tax returns, but doing so through short-term trading.Evidence shows that longer holding periods are associated with better performance. According to data from Dimensional Fund Advisors, over the 15 year period ending on 12/31/2015 the average holding period of a stock by U.S. equity mutual funds has been approximately one year.The data presented above shows that when equity funds were divided into quartiles based on their average holding period, a much higher percentage of funds with longer holding periods outperformed the benchmark over the full period than did funds in any of the other quartiles.The quartile of funds with the longest average holding period had an average holding period over 3.5 years and 29% of those funds outperformed their benchmark. This frequency of outperformance is almost twice as high as the 17% for all funds in the study, and more than three times as high as the 8% for the quartile of funds with the shortest holding period which averaged less than 6 months.All quartiles had the majority of the funds underperforming their benchmark over this 15-year period, a finding consistent with Why Passive Investing is an Excellent Default Choice – an Active Investor’s View.How to be a long-term investor Never put yourself in a position to be a forced seller. Price volatility only matters if you are forced to sell when prices are low. If you don’t have to sell (or even better, if you can arrange your circumstances so that you can deploy capital when assets are priced unreasonably cheaply), then price volatility is not going to hurt your long-term financial outcome. The best way to put yourself in this position is by matching the time when you will require funds to the type of investments that you make. For example, equities and other long-duration assets are not appropriate for those who will likely need a substantial portion of their investment within 3, and preferably 5, years in the future. So if you anticipate needing a large portion of your capital in the next few years, consider investing the amount that you will need in the short-term in lower return and lower volatility assets such as cash or short-term government bonds. This can give you the staying power to invest the rest of your assets appropriately for the long-term.Ignore news, opinions and commentary that is not likely to matter in 5 years. Specifically, be sure to ignore broad general fears about how a geopolitical or macroeconomic event is sure to affect prices in the short-term. There is no better way to ensure you are likely to do the exact opposite of what you should be doing than by getting caught up in the emotional roller-coaster of news reports and opinions about where the market will be at the end of the year. (Hint: nobody really knows where the market is headed in the short-term, but some find it entertaining to speculate nonetheless.)Avoid the principal/agent problem and misalignment of incentives. If you invest directly, then this isn’t a cause for concern, and your challenge is to overcome various behavioral biases and pressures. However, if you invest through an agent (e.g. a financial advisor or a fund manager), then make sure their incentives are aligned with long-term value creation on your behalf. Rest assured that if their compensation or job security depends on their short-term investment results, they are unlikely to act with a long-term time horizon which is most likely to benefit you.Few individuals or professionals are truly able to take the long view. There are too many behavioral and incentive-related pressures to do otherwise. However, the rewards for being able to follow a disciplined investing strategy focused on the long-term are likely to be meaningful for those who are able to do so.

Well, who doesn’t want to get rich but getting “rich via stock market” is a very difficult. I had been doing on-off trading for around 15 years but since last few years - I have started looking at stock market more seriously and have been trying to build a steady additional income stream via the medium. I would split in answer into two groups - 3 things you must do in stock market and 3 things which you must never do in stock market. 3 Things to do: (a) Always always always have a pre-defined stop loss. I have seen it multiple times in my own account, when loss of few hundreds rupees becomes loss of few thousands which then becomes loss of tens of thousands. See the reason is simple - when the loss is less, we tend to leave it (we think that loss is less and we can cut it anytime). Slowly the loss builds to a level where we start thinking, what is the point of cutting the trade now(loss has become more but still manageable) and the final stage - how low the stock can go(loss become substantial and hence we cannot cut it anymore and wait for days->weeks->years)? Also remember that their will be cases when after your stop loss is triggered and the stock will reverse direction. In these cases, you might feel that “I should have taken a little more risk”- try to stay away from this feeling because ultimately it will might impact future trades.  Remember to take care of your losses and your profits will take care of you. (b) Always have a pre-defined target - Depending upon your trading style (intraday or swing or positional or long term) you should have a realistic target. Once that target is hit, you can either take the profit or use trailing stop loss to keep increasing your profits. Having a target is important because without it, you are essentially going on a journey without knowing the destination!!!! (c) Diversify in various stocks- Always diversify in multiple stocks. For instance, if you have Rs 1 lakh to invest, I would recommend that you break them into 10 parts and invest in 10 different stocks. The reason is simple - “Noone knows where the market or a particular stock is headed”. Let it be the TV journalist on CNBC / Zee Business (whose only job is reporting on stock market) or twitter guru’s like Ashwini Gujral or newest breed of traders on Youtube selling their classes - NOONE KNOWS WHERE THE MARKETS IS HEADED. Hence, diversification is the only away to reduce the risk. 3 Things NOT TO DO: (a) Advisory services - Do not opt for advisory services. These people will simply take your money, empty your trading account in few days/weeks and will CHARGE you money for emptying your trading account. Let me give tell you,what happened when I got a call from advisory service few days ago: He - How’s the market going? Me - Fine. He - What kind of return are you making? Me - 2 to 3% per month(in good months) He - Oh, that’s all. I can get you 15–20% per month. Me - hahahahahhaha He - No seriously. Me - Quit your job, take personal loan at 18% per year and live happily ever after. He - hangs up (b) Futures and options - Trading in futures / options especially stocks F&O will make you poorer, sooner than you think is even possible. Trust me, you might make some money in couple of times but market will ultimately take take 2 –3 times the money you made. PS - I recently wrote an email to to my broker to deactivate F&O trading on my account. (c) FOMO - Fear Of Missing Out(FOMO) is one of the biggest reason for my losses. This is the phenomenon when we take a position in a stock before all the prerequisite conditions are met(whatever that analysis might be) because we fear that if we spend more time waiting the stock might go higher and we will lose out on profit. Remember, it is better to lose out on profit then to get into a losing trade. Okay, enough gyaan for first answer on stock market :)

The idea is to Start Early! The earlier you start the better your chancesof creating wealth in the Stock Market. And no matter what they feed youabout making a quick buck in the ‘short run’ everybody in the stockmarket knows that the real money is in the long run. For those who arepatient enough to wait it out. Having said that, not every company out there is worth waiting uponand many have proven to be Wealth Destroyers. For this purpose, one thumb rule to follow is- never invest in a companywhich you don’t understand. You need to pick ‘Wealth Creators’. The following Snapshot is an Example of few a ‘Wealth Creators’ inthe indian Stock Market:  So how do you start finding companies worth investing? You can’t suddenly decide one day and find your ideal pick. It is a process,for which you need to start by opening a Demat Account. Start readingInvesting websites, business newspapers, magazines or whatever you find comfortable . The idea is to familiarize yourself with all the macro and micro economic concepts that affect listed companies and the stock market as a whole. Once these concepts and jargons start making sense to you, you can try investing a part of your decided capital in “Blue Chips” The Concept of Blue Chips:  What is a 'Blue Chip' A blue chip is a nationally recognized, well-established and financially sound company. Blue chips generally sell high-quality, widely accepted products and services. Blue chip companies are known to weather downturns and operate profitably in the face of adverse economic conditions, which helps to contribute to their long record of stable and reliable growth.- Investopedia. Such companies have proven their mettle in the past and are known to weather the cyclical ups and downs in the economy over the years. The ideahere is to ‘start safe’. Since you are still a novice in the market, blue chipcompanies are your best bets to start out. For reasons such as:- Strong Market Share - Regular Dividends - Already established companies with a potential to grow further. Stock market consists of participants, and participants are human beings driven by two major emotions- “Fear of losing money” & “Greed for earning more”.Hence, by selecting a blue chip company you can control the emotion offear to a great extent, at the same time not being too greedy( Yes, the ideais to find a balance between the two). After you have made a few ‘safe bets’ its time to get started with the ‘real deal’ Fundamental Analysis:  Fundamental Analysis (FA) is a holistic approach to study a business. When an investor wishes to invest in a business for the long term (say 3 – 5 years) it becomes extremely essential to understand the business from various perspectives. It is critical for an investor to separate the daily short term noise in the stock prices and concentrate on the underlying business performance. Over the long term, the stock prices of a fundamentally strong company tend to appreciate, thereby creating wealth for its investors.- Zerodha Varsity Fundamental analysis is about understanding the company you are lookingto invest in from all possible perspectives for eg Financial Statements(P&L,Balance Sheet, Cash Flow), Ratio Analysis, Industry trends and other microand macro economic factors which might affect the company. The central idea is to estimate the “intrinsic value” of a Company and thenaccordingly make a decision to buy or not. If the intrinsic value is morethan its current market price than the company is a BUY and vice versa. Technical Analysis  Technical Analysis(TA) is a technique which is based on studying charts. Mainly, the ‘candle stick’ charts. TA helps us decide/recognize the trend of a particular stock based on the chart patterns created by the price movement in that stock. There are endless technical indicators available but as a long term investor, learning the basics of candlestick are enough, IMO. Technical Analysis is crucial for: -Recognizing the short term trend: Whether to purchase a stock or wait for its downtrend to end.- Finding an ideal ‘entry point’ -TA can help you identify the desiredentry points so that you dont end up buying a stock in its down trend. Concepts like Moving Averages, The Dow theory- Double Top and Doublebottom, 52 Week High-low, Fibonacci Retracement, Support & Resistance are worth understanding. Once you have Fundamental & Technical Analysis internalized youare well equipped to scope out your ‘Ideal Picks'. Now, how do you do that? I have personally derived two methods- either find a 'MOAT' or look for 'Value'. MOAT : This is a term coined by the veteran investor Warren Buffet. It basicallyrefers to a company with a competitive advantage in a particular industryover its competitors. The company is so well placed in that particular industry that it is virtually impossible for any competitor to take over. Companies with a MOAT possess huge revenue numbers and areonly bound to grow. So, if you identify such a MOAT and its Fundamental and Technical Analysis checks out, you have arrivedat your potential ‘Ideal pick’ Examples of MOAT: - Wal-mart Stores Inc (US):  -Pidlite Industries (India)  If you check into the historical Stock price , Dividend & Bonus trends of these two companies, you will realize why they qualify as ‘Moats’ Value Investing:This concept involves identifying that company which might turn outto be a potential MOAT in the future. The idea is to identify early withthe help of Fundamental Analysis and intrinsic valuation. Some of thecommon indicators for a value pick: - Low Price to Equity Ratio (P/E)- Low to Price to Book Ratio (P/Bv)- Low Debt to Equity ratio-Good OP and NP margins- Positive Cashflow from operations.- Prudent investment in Capex(expansion) activities. A value pick, identified early can give multi fold returns but it alsocomes with a down side of uncertainty ie it may or may not be able to grow or sustain as its still a fairly small business at the point ofinvestment. Therefore, research your companies well enough till you start understandingthem. Make your own check list and make sure FA, TA, industry trends andall other factors check out before you decide to invest your hard earned money.Once you do, stay patient and watch your money work for you. ;) I hope this write up was able to convey the basic idea about the foundationrequired for successful long term Stock Picking. One way to get rich from stocks is to bet on which direction they’ll move. That is, trade options. Nothing fancy. Just buying Puts and Calls and then selling them and taking your profit. A Put gives you the right to sell the underlying asset for a predetermined price, known as the strike price. And a Call gives you the right to buy the underlying asset. Typically, traders buy Calls when they are bullish and believe the underlying stock will rise in price. Likewise, they tend to buy Puts when they are bearish and think the stock’s price will fall. Options give you a way to leverage hundreds of shares of stocks and ETF shares without you having to buy the stock itself (which costs a lot more money), so they give you a way to profit from stocks without you buying the stocks and then hoping the stock’s price won’t plunge. But never put more than 10% of your account at risk into any one given trade. This is key to risk management. And stay away from the credit and debit spreads, and definitely stay away from short strangles (Google “Karen the Supertrader”). The only people who make money off those most of the time are the market makers and brokerage firms. Is it possible to make money with spreads (i.e. straddles, strangles, iron condors, butterflies, etc.)? Sure. Anything’s possible. But that doesn’t mean it’s probable. I don’t think highly of outfits that lure in people desperate for an income - usually those over age 50 who’ve been permanently pushed out of the job market due to age discrimination and who can’t afford to retire but are too young to draw a social security check - because most of the time, these spreads, which are touted as income-generating vehicles, end up costing more money than anticipated and loss of principal capital. With spreads, you only make money, which is narrowly limited by the premium you receive when opening the position, if the instrument moves only slightly in either direction and your contract expires out-of-the-money (OTM). But if the price moves too much in either direction, you run the risk of having the short leg of your spread going in-the-money (ITM), and then you run the risk of getting assigned (meaning you now have to find the money from somwhere to buy enough of the underlying asset). One Put or Call contract equals 100 shares of an underlying stock or exchange traded fund (ETF). You typically buy several contracts. So, keep that in mind in case you’re assigned. So, stick with just buying Puts and Calls to start with. No short sales. Granted, you won’t set the world on fire and not every trade will be a winner, but you won’t lose everything either - mainly because you don’t have to put as much capital at risk when buying options as you do when buying the stock outright.

In a linear fashion? Obviously not. Stocks move around a lot. Often, investors take crucial investment decisions when the stock has either rewarded them a lot or punished them a lot in the recent past. There’s nothing wrong in it as such. It’s simply human nature to respond to either high levels of euphoria or crushing stress. Take any great stock with a long history from any country in the world and I’m willing to bet my head that this will hold true.  Mohnish Pabrai, the famous investor, once said: “You don’t make money when you buy stocks. You don’t make money when you sell stocks. You make money by waiting.”  And he’s right. Good investors trade because they have something to do. Bad investors trade because they have to do something. Now, I will not deny the fact that getting rich from investing in stocks requires a business sense, mathematical acumen and incremental capital. But underlying the very essence of ‘making money’ in stocks in the deceiving act of waiting. People don’t get rich from stocks by understanding a business end-to-end. The principle of successful equity portfolio management is very simple: buy stocks that go up, and sell them when they’ve gone up. However, putting that into practice is difficult. We’ve collected a few nuggets of experience and wisdom here, some obvious, some not-so-obvious, that’ll help you think about how you invest and how you shape your portfolio:  1. First, there are no geniuses in the business world. There is hard work, experience, and not a little luck. So, don’t make big bets early in your investment career; you’ll make mistakes, learn with small amounts of money and lower risks until you’ve gained that experience. Don’t trust anyone who says that they are a genius, and don’t invest in a stock because you think the promoter is a genius. Follow investment professionals with long careers and learn from them. 2. Stockmarkets have cycles – short term, long term, and generational. Investing styles change (value, growth, momentum). Decision and research technology changes (from reading yesterday’s newspaper, to machine learning and big data). But whatever the environment, whatever technique you find most useful, always remember that the price of a stock, or the level of a market, is determined by a simple, visceral battle between buyers and sellers. Buyers anticipate profits (‘greed’). Sellers feel that the risk of holding is too high (‘fear’). Fear and greed are eternal. They’re even inherent in computer models, which are either programmed to reflect human expertise, or reacting to human activity. A really experienced investor is always finely tuned to the changing balance of fear and greed affecting them. 3. Most of us have subliminal (or not so subliminal!) feelings and opinions anchored to the history of our investments. But investment is only ever in the future. It starts now, and ends only when you realise the investment (in part or in full). What you paid for an investment, whether you’ve received dividends, why you originally decided to invest… none of this matters. They are irrecoverable costs or experiences. This principle of sunk cost is one of the clearest and most useful investment guidelines you can apply. With a blank sheet of paper, today, right now, would you want to hold this investment? Is it a good investment from this point on (and, in a portfolio context, does it justify displacing other potential investments)? This is one of the hardest rules to follow. We don’t want to acknowledge a loss-making investment. We may want to sell an investment that’s done well and put cash in the bank, even though it is still a great proposition. We might remember how smart we felt when we bought it, or feel we put so much research effort in we should hold it. We’d like to prove we’re right. We’d like to prove our colleagues wrong. But each time you review your portfolio, look at it as if it were a brand new portfolio, judge its merits accordingly, and you’ll be a better investor. 4. You can’t control when the market will give you a return on your investment. You have to be invested. Staying on the sidelines waiting for the right moment, doesn’t work. There’s evidence to suggest that up to 40% of your annualised return over a 10-year period comes from only 10 trading days, and that 2/3 comes from only 20 trading days… but you don’t know which are the “big win” days until they’ve happened. Similarly, if you have an opinion about an investment, unless you express that opinion by owning the stock, it really doesn’t matter if you’re proved right. You have to be there. This may seem a really obvious comment, but many investors do try to time their entry and exit into the market. Most professionals would prefer to stay invested. 5. Anything that you can measure is in the past. As an investor, you are interested only in the period from now, until the moment you exit the investment – i.e., the future. Of course it’s impossible to quantify the future! But do not place too much reliance on data, on history, on quantified risk models; anything that relies on measured experience can only tell you about the past, about history. Conversely, qualitative information has a better chance of giving you pointers to how the future might look. For example, reading up on the board of directors of a company, on the outlook for its industry, or newspaper articles, can create a holistic picture of what the company is like; this may well feel like a subjective opinion, but a well-researched subjective opinion is likely to be more insightful than a spreadsheet full of historic data analysis. 6. And finally, many of our members are telling us that this is the time to move to active management – picking your stocks carefully and creating a thoughtful portfolio. Indexed investment has become huge, and perhaps now the dominant influence on markets (by some measures, more than $4 trillion is invested in stocks through index investment). There are good reasons for this, and certainly for many investors this is the most appropriate way to buy stocks. But an index fund will buy a stock just because it’s in the index, without regard for value or prospects. That $4 tn is, in effect, dumb money, and is creating huge value distortions in stocks globally. For investors that have the ability, this is an excellent time to be picking stocks carefully, or investing in active mutual funds. Invest wisely and with common sense!

Hi, Jesse, Someone like Warren Buffett is good evidence that you can get wealthy from investing in stocks. However, Buffett and his team are extremely knowledgeable and follow a tried-and-true investment philosophy. Knowledge is power. If you don’t know what you are doing with investments, there is an excellent chance that you will achieve returns less than what you are expecting. Before you decide to become your own investment manager, read, watch, and learn. Spending a bit of time and money to prepare yourself for this job (and it IS a job) is essential. If you don’t have the time or money to invest in training yourself to be your personal investment manager, I suggest you consider investing in mutual funds or exchange traded funds that are managed by professionals who have exhibited a multi-year track record of achieving good results. In my case, I put my 401K contributions into a Target Year fund. The philosophy with such funds is that the investment profile (stocks vs. bonds, etc.) changes over time, based upon how many years remain between the current date and the fund’s target year. For example, if you invested in a Target Year 2060 fund — 40 years out from now — the fund’s assets would be heavily weighted toward growth stocks, because they have a history of providing greater annual returns. However, greater potential returns essentially ALWAYS come with greater potential annual losses. Such investments have a higher mean annual return, but they also have a higher standard deviation on their annual return. The premise with that 2060 target year fund is that, over a 20-year period or so, there will be some losing years, but over that first 20 years of the fund the annual returns will approach the mean and you will make more money in the long term. Now, as you get closer to the target year, the premise is that the fund holders are getting closer to retirement and are less tolerant to losses. So, the fund’s assets will transition into having a preponderance of incoming-producing securities, such as higher-dividend stocks and bonds.

Your aim is to be the next buffet, but you probably don't have all the parts and the ones that you need may cost more than you have. Warren Buffett's first-ever stock purchase illustrates two very important principles of successful investing strategies: patience and the importance of timing. Patience is indeed a virtue for investors. Buffett exercised patience well in waiting for the market to come back in his favor, but he failed to be patient enough to take full advantage of the stock's profit potential. Having successfully weathered the storm, he failed to observe the adage, "Let profits run." Still, he did make a profit on his very first stock trade. There are some fundamentals every investor should be aware of that may help them identify suitable strategies - 1. Set Goal & Expectation - There's nothing wrong with hoping for the best from your investments, but you could be heading for trouble if your financial goals are based on unrealistic assumptions. 2. Determine Risk Tolerance - Before you start investing, an investor must analyse his risk appetite. Risk appetite is the amount of risk an investor is willing to take while investing. An investor’s risk profile can be conservative, moderate, moderately aggressive or aggressive. An investor’s risk appetite also depends on his financial position and other financial obligations. 3. Hold Investments For Long-Term - Buy and hold strategy works best with equities in order to reap maximum profit. Long-term investment strategies tend to look ahead in decades and the buy and hold approach works with stocks as long as you have a decade or two to play with. 4. Stick To A Single Trading Pattern - Traders must identify an appropriate trading pattern and adhere to it. The best way to check if a trading method is suitable for you or not, you should execute a number of trades at a time following a single method. If you lose money consistently instead of gaining profits, find ways to improve your trading strategy. 5. Do Your Own Research Before Investing - Collect information about companies, its financial position, its future plans, any mergers or acquisitions, dividend/return history etc.

5 golden rules of investing in stock markets The lure of big money has always thrown investors into the lap of stock markets. However, making money in equities is not easy. It not only requires oodles of patience and discipline, but also a great deal of research and a sound understanding of the market, among others. Added to this is the fact that stock market volatility in the last few years has left investors in a state of confusion. They are in a dilemma whether to invest, hold or sell in such a scenario. Although no sure-shot formula has yet been discovered for success in stock markets, here are some golden rules which, if followed prudently, may increase your chances of getting a good return: 1. Avoid the herd mentality The typical buyer's decision is usually heavily influenced by the actions of his acquaintances, neighbours or relatives. Thus, if everybody around is investing in a particular stock, the tendency for potential investors is to do the same. But this strategy is bound to backfire in the long run. No need to say that you should always avoid having the herd mentality if you don't want to lose your hard-earned money in stock markets. The world's greatest investor Warren Buffett was surely not wrong when he said, "Be fearful when others are greedy, and be greedy when others are fearful!" 2. Take informed decision Proper research should always be undertaken before investing in stocks. But that is rarely done. Investors generally go by the name of a company or the industry they belong to. This is, however, not the right way of putting one's money into the stock market. 3. Invest in business you understand Never invest in a stock. Invest in a business instead. And invest in a business you understand. In other words, before investing in a company, you should know what business the company is in. 4. Don't try to time the market One thing that even Warren Buffett doesn't do is to try to time the stock market, although he does have a very strong view on the price levels appropriate to individual shares. A majority of investors, however, do just the opposite, something that financial planners have always been warning them to avoid, and thus lose their hard-earned money in the process. "So, you should never try to time the market. In fact, nobody has ever done this successfully and consistently over multiple business or stock market cycles. Catching the tops and bottoms is a myth. It is so till today and will remain so in the future. In fact, in doing so, more people have lost far more money than people who have made money," says Anil Chopra, group CEO and director, Bajaj Capital. 5.Follow a disciplined investment approach Historically it has been witnessed that even great bull runs have shown bouts of panic moments. The volatility witnessed in the markets has inevitably made investors lose money despite the great bull runs. However, the investors who put in money systematically, in the right shares and held on to their investments patiently have been seen generating outstanding returns. Hence, it is prudent to have patience and follow a disciplined investment approach besides keeping a long-term broad picture in mind.

Assuming inflation to be 5% at the end of year.  But that’s not the end of story, while the value of your deposit has soared, the prices have also gone up. That’s due to Inflation. So you’re left with “lesser ability” to buy goods and services. The lesser ability to buy goods/services is due to the fact that now you can buy less number of goods/services with same amount of money due to price rise. Say earlier with Rs.1000( in the beginning of the year) you could buy 100 Chocolate Bars.Fast forward to end of year the price of 1 Choco Bars is Rs.10.5(10∗[100+5duetoinflation]) Now ask your self this simple question how many Choco Bars can you buy with money in your hand right now had you not “invested”(Bank in our case) that money?Most likely your answer would be 95 Choco Bars (1000/10.5=95) Now ask yourself this, Earlier i could buy 100 Bars @ Rs 10 per bar but nowI’m able to buy just 95 bars with that same amount.
